awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Influence of phosphorus deficiency on enigmatic biological methane production in oxic freshwater lakes
awd_abstract_narration:
Atmospheric levels of methane have risen 150% since the Industrial Revolution, and continue to increase.  Although energy sector and agricultural sources are major contributors, natural microbiological sources account for roughly half of total global methane emissions.  Microbial methane production has long been assumed to be an anoxic process, carried out only under conditions of extremely low to zero oxygen. Recent research has demonstrated the potential for microbial methane production to occur in oxygenated upper waters of lakes and oceans through a previously unappreciated metabolic pathway present in microorganisms.  Under conditions of phosphorus deficiency, certain bacteria can utilize otherwise unreactive organic molecules known as methylphosphonates to meet their phosphorus requirements, releasing methane in the process.  The extent to which this mechanism supports the out-gassing of methane from lakes to the atmosphere is unknown, as are the consequences of changing environmental conditions upon it.  This project will address this knowledge gap by investigating the distributions, rates of and controls on aerobic methane production in Flathead Lake and 18 other Montana lakes of varying phosphorus deficiency status.  Because atmospheric deposition of pollutant nitrogen and deliberate measures to curtail phosphorus inputs to lakes can both lead to phosphorus deficiency, it is crucial that we know whether these factors may have the unexpected consequence of enhancing methane emissions.  This research will also directly support the education, field and laboratory experiences of graduate and undergraduate students and will provide training to local high school teachers from Native American (Kootenai and Salish) tribal lands.

This project will evaluate temporal and spatial variability in microbially-mediated, oxic methane production across lakes with varying phosphorus availability in western Montana. It is guided by the overarching hypothesis: diffusive effluxes of methane from oxic freshwater lakes are directly influenced by the nature and severity of ecosystem nutrient (nitrogen, phosphorus) deficiencies. A combination of observational and experimental approaches employing chemical, stable isotopic, metagenomic and PCR-based gene analyses will be used to examine: 1) time and space variability in the concentration, stable isotope composition, and net production of methane in freshwater lakes in Montana, focusing on Flathead Lake; 2) The extent to which microbial methylphosphonate degradation results in net production of methane in these lakes; 3) The functional diversity, abundances, and transcriptional activities of microorganisms involved in both phosphonate and methane cycling; and 4) How the stoichiometry (specifically nitrogen:phosphorus ratios) of aquatic nutrient (inorganic and total) pools influences oxic methane production and expression of methane cycling functional genes. The study will provide a systematic evaluation of microbial methane sources and the potential contribution of methylphosphonate degradation as a source of methane in oxic freshwater lakes. Results from this project will provide new insights and advance current understanding of coupled interactions between carbon and phosphorus cycling in freshwater lake habitats.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Methane (CH4) is the largest component of the natural gas used for global energy production.  Yet, CH4 is also a potent greenhouse gas and atmospheric concentrations of CH4 are increasing, with consequences to Earth’s climate.  Despite its global relevance to energy and climate, fluxes of CH4 by natural sources of CH4 remain poorly well constrained. Among the natural sources, the emission of microbially-produced CH4 from freshwater environments is thought to be a significant component of the global CH4 budget, but estimates of its magnitude vary widely. Production of CH4 by microbes (methanogenesis) has historically thought to be carried out exclusively in environments devoid of oxygen. Hence, in aquatic ecosystems, methanogenesis has been assumed to be mostly relegated to the sediments, where oxygen becomes depleted due to respiratory consumption of organic matter deposited from the overlying water and surrounding watershed. However, for decades studies of CH4 concentrations in both well-oxygenated oceans and lakes  find that CH4 concentrations are in excess of that due to exchange with the air and transport from the sediments.  This condition, termed the methane paradox, has been the subject of vigorous debate and on-going study.

Our project examined the importance of an understudied and poorly understood CH4-generating microbial process in lakes across Northwest Montana, with particular focus on Flathead Lake, the largest, natural, freshwater lake in the western United States. Our preliminary work in Flathead Lake identified supersaturated subsurface CH4 concentrations in the fully oxygenated lake water. Based on recent studies in the ocean, we hypothesized that lake CH4 was being produced as a byproduct of microorganism use of methylphosphonate (MPn) - an uncommon organic molecule containing reduced phosphorus –under the conditions of extreme inorganic phosphate scarcity.  We posited that the very low phosphate levels in Flathead Lake would select for microbes capable of using MPn as a phosphorus source for nutrition, thereby generating CH4 as a by-product, and that this process would significantly contribute to the net emission of CH4 from the lake to the atmosphere.

To address our hypothesis, we used an interdisciplinary approach that included: (1) time- and depth-resolved measurements of CH4 and associated physical, chemical and biological parameters in Flathead Lake over three years; (2) analyses of the stable isotopes of the carbon (13C) and hydrogen (2H) atoms in the CH4 molecule, which can provide "fingerprints" of methane sources and sinks; (3) metagenomic characterization of microbial communities and functional genes crucial to methane and phosphorus metabolism; (4) targeted incubation experiments that examined how nutrient (nitrogen and phosphorus) availability impacts oxic CH4 generation; and (5) sampling and rate measurements of CH4 dynamics and microorganisms that catalyze CH4 generation and consumption in Flathead Lake. Together, these integrative approaches allowed us to answer questions about how rapidly CH4 is cycling in Flathead Lake, which organisms drive that cycling, what are the metabolic functions of microorganisms involved in CH4 cycling, and to what extent availability of nutrients like nitrogen and phosphorus control CH4 dynamics in the lake.

We found that the genetic potential for oxic CH4 production exists among diverse microorganisms not only in Flathead Lake but commonly throughout the lakes studied.  Yet, oxic CH4 production remains low and appears responsible for only a minor fraction of CH4 emissions from Flathead Lake to the atmosphere.  Our experiments revealed that CH4 production was not influenced by only adding nitrate or phosphate, but that certain organisms did respond to the addition of MPn, and that the rate of CH4 production by using MPn was controlled by both the availability of MPn and organic carbon.  While low phosphorus does appear to favor the microbes that can use MPn for cellular phosphorus demands, this pathway does not seem to be particularly important to the methane budget of our primary study lake.  These findings suggest that more attention needs to be paid to alternative explanations to solve the CH4 paradox.  In future studies, we will be trying to better separate complex physical CH4 transport processes from other microbiological CH4-generating pathways.

Crucial to the success of our project was the involvement of early career scientists (postdoctoral researchers, and graduate and undergraduate students); these young scholars led the authorship of four peer-reviewed publications originating from this research project, and most have moved on to advanced degree programs or faculty positions.  In addition to postdoctoral and student support, this project supported costs incurred by students participating in the Aquatic Microbial Ecology summer course held at Flathead Lake Biological Station (FLBS). In addition, this project enabled us to host local area science teachers as part of a workshop on watershed stewardship, engage with local high school students in the Salish- Kootenai College STEM program, and develop high school lesson plans on use of eDNA to detect aquatic organisms.
